title: Taylor welcomes Labor energy switch
text:
"How many times are we going to let it kill us? Indeed, how many leaders do we want to lose to it?'' he said.

Mr Taylor said "we would love Labor to support our policy''.

"They are clearly recognising the error of their ways.''

But shadow climate and energy minister Mark Butler slapped down Mr Fitzgibbon's idea, telling Guardian Australia it would be inconsistent with the Paris agreement.

"It would lead to global warming of more than 3 degrees and, for that reason, Labor cannot support that target. That has been a consistent position of ours since we first took advice about what Tony Abbott’s target would mean for climate change,'' he said.

Asked at the Summit about Mr Fitzgibbon’s idea, Victorian Minister for Energy, Environment and Climate Change Lily D'Ambrosio said she had no idea what motivated him to call for a reduction in the target.

“I’m not particularly interested in what a federal opposition does,” she said.

“We have a very strong and ambitious policy and we took that to the last state election and, we all know the result of that election, so we will continue to implement our policies and get them done.”

Advertisement

According to Ms D’Ambrosio, Victoria’s ambitious policies are providing the investor certainty not found in other states, which is why it has attracted 43 per cent of the nation’s total new energy project investment.

She said the energy market had reached a point that it needed more intervention from all governments and that the energy debate should not be seen through an ideological prism.

“We can’t simply protect existing interests,” she said.

“The current rules are designed for a different era but the energy market operator seems to just back the status quo. Every day we spend waiting is another day that the issues of reliability, security and affordability become more acute.”

Ms D’Ambrosio said it had been a year since state and federal energy ministers last met, with the next Council of Australian Government energy council meeting scheduled for late next month.

"For me, November 22 cannot come fast enough," she said.

Ms D’Ambrosio said Labor in Victoria wants to work with the Commonwealth to secure more energy supply and build a transmission network of the future. But the federal government must first create a system that provides the right combination of investment and rule changes to ensure the nation’s future energy readiness.

She also said the Victorian government’s ban on fracking will stay in place while the science “is still out”.

“We are very clear on our policy decision around fracking as we don’t believe there is sufficient confidence in the science to give farmers the certainty they need (about) what the impact will be on water supply.”

She said she could not see the pressing need to access Victoria’s unconventional gas reserves because Australia had sufficient gas but allowed “too much of it to be exported”.

“The federal government has the mechanisms and authority to tackle the challenge of domestic gas shortages but it needs to consider the amount of gas allowed to be exported so there are sufficient supplies available domestically,” she said.
description: ALP frontbencher Joel Fitzgibbon's comments on emissions targets suggest the federal opposition might be in search of a new climate policy.
